bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, March 13, 1942

div1.p: Hench comments on details in Wood's manuscript of her book on Reed. He reflects on the difficulties in planning his own book.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, March 13, 1942
div1.p:
First let me thank you sincerely for the fine copy of Kelly's book.
When I sent you the advertisement about it I was afraid you'd think it was a not
very subtle hint that you should replace the copy I sent you, but I assure you
again that was not my purpose. I thought you might like to complete for yourself
a set of the three editions thereof. And so I will continue to send you what ad-
vertisements of them I can find. Meanwhile I will accept this copy with pleasure,
not for myself but for the three-edition set I plan to give W. and J.

I have received your manuscript chapters 18 et seq., and have read it
with much interest. I am delighted with it and congratulate you sincerely. I am
very surprised about one thing, however, and that is that I thought you were writing
a book for children, and my definition of children is kids under 15 years of age.
From what I have read of your manuscript I would say its appeal would be, not for
kids, but for young people of college age and indeed for laymen of all ages for that
matter. I do think that much of it is over the heads of school-kids for whom I
thought you were writing it. But that's just one man's opinion and if it sells
better for grown-ups than for kids you should worry!

Just between us (and implying no hidden meanings whatever) I'm beginning
to wonder seriously whether there is any use for me to write my story after that of
Truby and that of yourself appears! But we shall see what we shall see, and if mine
never sees the light of day I've had a whale of a lot of fun on it anyhow.

I do envy you one thing. In planning my own book I've debated and debated
as to whether I should manufacture “likely conversation” out of more or less whole
cloth or stick strictly to facts. Conversation does help tremendously but my whole
background of scientific training has been to say nothing or write nothing that couldn't
be absolutely proven. And who knows what Reed et al said to each other. You are
not bound by such restrictions; hence your manuscript is lively with chatty conver-
sation and I must say the conversation you've manufactured is infinitely more appro-
priate to the characters involved than the highly dramatized and unnecessarily pro-
fane conversations Sidney Howard manufactured for “Yellow Jack”. (Me thinks you
borrowed with slight alterations one or two of his less purple conversation-pieces;
am I right? But that's O.K.)

Now for some comments. I have made no attempt to edit it. That's not my
function. I do think a sentence here and there could be smoothed up and their
parsing made less complicated. But all in all it's swell. May I make some individual
comments:

Chap. 18, p. 8: “Fewer than 1000 Americans stopped bullets.....” It
is the conventional thing to say (as I did in one of my talks) that disease especially
yellow fever killed more soldiers than did the bullets, but I confess I'm having a
little difficulty in finding trustworthy statistics on the incidence of fatal wounds,
non-fatal wounds, fatal and non-fatal yellow fever. The reports of the Surgeon-General
for the years 1898-1902 are in my hands but did you run across any other dope on this
point? Where did you get the reference to the sentence re 1000 Americans?
Miss Wood
March 13, 1942

Chapt. 18, p. 10. Where did you get the reference to the “only $20,000
to spend” on the medical corps? This is a very interesting chapter about a phase
of Reed's life I've so far not interested myself in much, although recently I bought
a fine copy of the detailed report of Reed, Vaughan and Shakespeare. Haven't had
time to read it yet.

Chapt. 19, p. 26. I have always been thrilled with the paper of Stubbins
Fforth. What a grand name! I've had his paper microfilmed. How nearly he found the
secret!

Chapt. 19, pp. 30-31. There is a great and sudden change between the
context on p. 30 and that on p. 31. On page 30 you are exploring the mind of
Sternberg and showing why he decided to create the Board. Without interrupting
devices (**********) or a new chapter head you suddenly plunge on page 31 to Reed
on a boat down in Tampa. Some plunge! I do think the connection should be
smoothed out.

Chapt. 19, p. 32. “Quemados seven miles west of Havana.” I've seen this
variously stated as 9 kilometers west of Havana, 5 miles west, etc. etc. I've
travelled it many times and measured it with the autometer but it all depends on what
part of Havana is considered the measuring point. I've gotten so many figures myself
I'm confused. For example, in the Senate Document 61, pl 10 McCaw speaks of Camp
Lazear (in Quemados) as “about 4 miles from Habana”. On page 16 Kean says “Camp
Lazear----about 4 miles from Habana.” On page 68 Reed et al speak of “Habana, 6
miles distant.” In the Annual Report of Major General Leonard Wood for 1901 on
page 6 (third chapter (?) - “Roster of Troops” etc.) it says “Columbia Barracks,
Marianao Railroad Station, Quemados, 6 miles from Havana.” In Agramonte's “Inside
History of a Great Medical Discovery,” Scientific Monthly Dec. 1915 he says on the
first page - “Columbia Barracks---distant about 8 miles from the city of Havana.”
Somewhere else (I can't find the reference at the moment) Camp Columbia is referred
to as 9 kilometers. Now 9 kilometers about 5.6 miles (am I right?). So why not
accept Wood's statement and call it 6 miles instead of seven miles. (All this is
much ado about not very much but it annoys me to see so many different distances
given. It makes it harder to satisfy people that we have actually found Camp
Lazear where it is).

Chapt. 19, p. 34. You suddenly shift scenes without adequate warning, ex-
planation or interrupting typographical devices. One minute you are with Lazear,
Reed et al on the verandah at Camp Columbia. A sentence later “Sternberg (in
Washington) seated behind his desk, nods agreement to Reed's conversation 1000 miles
away. The inference is that Sternberg was in Quemados.

Chapt. 20, p. 39. Whose version are you taking re the spread of the
epidemic in Quemados? You are apparently combining the version given by Reed (Senate
Doc. p. 94) and that given in Kean's diary entry of June 8, p. 169, where he recapitu-
lated the list of yellow fever victims Kean says the epidemic first started in #20
Gen. Lee Street, then went to 102 Real and then to 89 Real, etc. Reed who wasn't in
Havana then and who must have gotten this dope later from Kean or Lazear or Ames,
said the epidemic began at 102 Real, then #20 Gen. Lee, then to a house (number not
mentioned) right across the street. I have visited all of these houses and photographed
each individually after finding out from old time residents that the numbers had not
been changed. Reed's description as to 102 Real and then 20 Gen. Lee is obviously
wrong. Unfortunately Kean was apparently wrong in placing the two Caesar brothers
(who died) in 89 Real for I visited 89 Real and talked at length with one of its
Miss Wood
- 3 -
March 13, 1942
inmates who had lived there for years and years, remembered the epidemic, etc. The
Caesars never lived in #89. I think otherwise you'd better follow Kean's diary.
Major Edmunds lived at #27 Gen. Lee St. which is not right across from #20 Gen. Lee
St. but is actually across the street but 1 1/2 blocks nearer Camp Columbia (2 streets
cross between #20 and #27 Gen. Lee. Major Kean had formerly lived in #27 himself.
Right across from #27 Gen. Lee St. and 1 1/2 blocks from #20 Gen. Lee is #16 Gen. Lee
where a Mrs. Fenn (according to Kean) or a Mrs. Muller (according to Dr. Angles) got
yellow fever. (See the diagrams enclosed). I still haven't found the map of this
epidemic--the house to house map made out by Ames (possibly with Lazear's help) which
Reed borrowed. It is mentioned in several places, among them in a letter to Ames
from Reed. But I did find in the National Archives a diagram which I microfilmed.
I enclose a rough copy. It was from a Report of Major Havard to the Adjutant General,
Division of Cuba, dated June 18, 1900.

I suggest that you don't worry about this. Perhaps you will let it go as
you have it and I will finally straighten it out by putting together these various
references after comparing them with Lazear's notes and some notes Miss Ames just
sent me last week. But please don't publish these diagrams. I'd like to reserve them
for my own study. Incidentally you say, “Then it skipped to the square at the end
of the block. You haven't quoted very clearly what Reed wrote on page 94, Sen. Doc.
where he said “to the distance of a square”, etc. A square and a block are the same,
aren't they?

Chapt. 20, p. 40. “Turning off the Calzada Real into the hospital grounds
......” This gives the impression that the hospital grounds were next to or bounded
by or at least very close to Calzada Real. As a matter of fact in some spots Calzada
Real is 1/2 mile from the hospital grounds so I suggest you say “Turning off the
Calzada Real and proceeding onward to the hospital grounds”......or some such.

Chapt. 20, p. 43. As to whether Carter's paper influenced Reed primarily
or Lazear primarily I suspect that Reed didn't appreciate its significance until
Lazear brought it forcibly to his attention by his work or by the notes in his
(Lazear's) notebook. All I can do to help you is to inclose photostats of 3 letters
sent to Mrs. Lazear by Dr. Thayer. (Please return these to me promptly as they are
the only copies I have.)

I still strongly suspect that although Reed (when he first went to Cuba)
may have already decided to investigate the mosquito theory sometime and somewhere
along the line, he wasn't impressed with this theory enough to put it first on their
agenda and really wasn't impressed by it (even after the Pinar del Rio guardhouse
affair) until Lazear had plugged away at it alone for quite awhile. Lazear apparently
never had any use for the infectious theory and from the very beginning he tackled
the mosquito idea.

Chapt. 21, p. 64. “When he confided his suspicions to Kean, Truby and the
other Board members.....” Kean told me he never heard this idea from Reed, didn't
know of Reed's suspicions until Truby told him just a few years ago (Better check
this) I believe Trub wrote me (I can't find it today in the mass of correspondence
I've had from him) that he believes Reed told his suspicions to only one or two
(including Truby). Why not avoid specific names as I did on page 6 of the enclosed
reprint (marked).

Chapt. 21, p. 67. I suppose you got this from Kean but I can't imagine
one soldier addressing another as “Ranny” unless as you infer Lee had known Kean as
Miss Wood
- 4 -
March 13, 1942
a child. Where did Lee know Kean's father? Is this conversation real (i.e. from
Kean) or fabricated?

Chapt. 22, p. 74, paragraph 2. “The non-immunes could go out on such
necessary errands as getting supplies, etc...” This is of course a slip. You meant
the immunes. that is, the 3 immune members of the detachment (see Sen. Doc. p. 71).
Reed et al specifically states (p. 71) “A non-immune person having once left this
camp, was not permitted to return to it under any circumstances whatever.”

Chapt. 22, p. 77. One version infers that one of the 3 (Cooke, Folk or
Jernegan) vomited. I've never found out whether this is true and if so, who it was.
All Reed says (Sen. Doc. 84) is that “the odor was so offensive as to compel them to
retreat from the house.” You infer that Cooke was the one most affected. Do you
know this for sure? It is one of the questions I plan to ask Cooke himself when
I visit him this spring.

Chapt. 22, p. 79. It should be Bomiato, not Voniato (see Kean's paper
“Walter Reed, Dedication of His Birthplace”-- in Military Surgeon, March, 1928,
p. 301.

I wish I had time to go over your manuscript more carefully. But since
you want it back almost at once I've only gone over it once. Please let me see
a complete copy (galley proof or book) as soon as you can and if I can help more,
please let me know. I just received the last batch of material I had photostated
at the National Archives. In addition to Reed's personal file I found a most
minute account of his whereabouts written in longhand by some clerk. Mr. Thomases
found it for me--it is the Register of Medical Officers, Vol. 11. I couldn't find
all the entries but pages 149, 150, 151 and 88 give Reed's whereabouts from Sept.
1893 to his death. Doubtless the preceding data could be found, if you still want
to check his earlier whereabouts in detail.

Have you ever corresponded with Mrs. Lazear? I don't imagine your book
will satisfy Lazear's widow or relatives and of course it will make Carroll's
son (nasty fellow!) see red once more (for the millionth time, I guess). I think
you have given Lazear more credit than many writers but you have only hinted at the
prime importance of his work during the first phases of the Board's work. But I
can see that in a book on Reed you couldn't give Lazear the credit that I can,
writing on the whole story, not on Reed's part alone.

Let me hear how things go and when the book is to appear, as I am anxious
for an early copy. Will it be illustrated?
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
